questions.question_text: How does Monitoring Console (MC) initially identify the server role(s) of a new Splunk Instance?

A customer has downloaded the Splunk App for AWS from Splunkbase and installed it in a search head cluster following the instructions using the deployer. A power user modifies a dashboard in the app on one of the search head cluster members. The app containing an updated dashboard is upgraded to the latest version by following the instructions via the deployer.
What happens?

choices.C: The updated dashboard will be available to the power user.
choices.A: The updated dashboard will not be deployed globally to all users, due to the conflict with the power user's modified version of the dashboard.
choices.B: Applying the search head cluster bundle will fail due to the conflict.
choices.D: The updated dashboard will not be available to the power user; they will see their modified version.

discussion.content: i assume D is correct answer. as deployer does not override user/UI modifications

This is a prime example of reading every word of the question. The "updated" version of the dashboard is referring to the one in the Application update. The one that the power user modified (their) is the one that they will see. The correct answer is "D".

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct one. The local copy on the search head cluster will win.

Selected Answer: D
Definitely D.
When a user have a role that can modify a dashboard, if he do it, the original xml file is untouched and stay in "default" folder but the new one is in "local" folder and take precedence over the one in "default".
When the app is updated, the original file is updated BUT the file in local is untouched and still have precedence (tested right now on a dev platform).

Selected Answer: D
D, the deployer update default folder,

the correct answer is C
https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/8.2.6/DistSearch/PropagateSHCconfigurationchanges#:~:text=The%20deployer%20is%20a%20Splunk,is%20called%20the%20configuration%20bundle. 
App upgrades and runtime changes
Because of how configuration file precedence works, changes that users make to apps at runtime get maintained in the apps through subsequent upgrades.

Say, for example, that you deploy the 1.0 version of some app, and then a user modifies the app's dashboards. When you later deploy the 1.1 version of the app, the user modifications will persist in the 1.1 version of the app.

comments.content: yes but in that case it is available for every one, not only for power users

questions.question_text: A customer's deployment server is overwhelmed with forwarder connections after adding an additional 1000 clients. The default phone home interval is set to 60 seconds. To reduce the number of connection failures to the DS what is recommended?

choices.C: Leave the phone home interval at 60 seconds.
choices.A: Create a tiered deployment server topology.
choices.D: Increase the phone home interval to 600 seconds.
choices.B: Reduce the phone home interval to 6 seconds.

discussion.content:
PS recommendation is to always increase the default phone home to 600 sec before leaving site so before adding additional Deployers I would do that..
So D would be my answer

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct one.

Selected Answer: D
D, 600 secs

Selected Answer: D
D, 600 seconds

Selected Answer: D
Answer "D"

D could also be an answer if the customer doesn't have enough resources to create the Tiered Deployment Server Structure.
https://gist.github.com/sworisbreathing/d236895568eaf31da579

IE slowing down the phone home time to 10 minutes would slow down the connection collisions. 
Third option not here would be to use DNS name for the DS then utilize Round Robin or some other type of Load Balancing to handle connection requests.
C, has not hashed it
C, text is in clear
C is correct.

questions.question_text: What is the Splunk PS recommendation when using the deployment server and building deployment apps?

choices.B: Only deploy Splunk PS base configurations via the deployment server.
choices.A: Carefully design smaller apps with specific configuration that can be reused.
choices.D: Carefully design bigger apps containing multiple configs.
choices.C: Use $SPLUNK_HOME/etc/system/local configurations on forwarders and only deploy TAs via the deployment server.
